options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had recorded lectures that were posted to the Umbrella Canvas page every week.
Combination of recorded lecture and virtual seminar
This class also included lectures, although these were asynchronous and virtual due to the pandemic.
Recorded lectures posted on Canvas along with virtual discussion seminars.
N/A
lecture
Zoom seminars, recorded lectures, office hours

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to write a paper and discuss in class.

A better understanding of how to analyze literary texts, how to write 4-6 page papers about the smallest of passages, how to think critically about modern applications of these ancient stories, and how to reflect upon your work.
Discussion skills especially organizing my thoughts when speaking, writing more clearly, close reading and analysis

One of the best skills I learned while taking this course was the importance of thoroughly editing a paper, and different methods for doing so. Often, the class before a paper was due was reserved for peer editing, which was quite helpful.
How to read a lot and develop a cogent and well-developed argument

writing skills
analysis
I developed insight into how to deep read literature passages and how to write papers in a clearer way.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish I wrote better. I also wish I knew how to better improve.

Strengths: The awesome professors and material. All of the professors (not just mine) were EXTREMELY knowledgeable about the material. The material in and of itself was also awesome, from The Odyssey to Dante's Divine Comedy we covered quite a bit of antiquity. 

Weaknesses: This is a sentiment echoed year after year person after person, but the speed at which the entire program goes is frustrating. You don't really get to go into depth with the texts and it can leave you feeling like you don't always have the best analysis or even understanding of the text at hand. I wish we had more time to spend on each work but I also understand that's how it goes. However, from the three classes, I feel as if Literature was the easiest to still grasp at this pace. 

Improvement: Professor Periano and Professor LeVen were incredible and my only real gripe is with the speed of the program. Lectures (which my professors don't have any control over) could've been posted earlier as it was difficult to watch them sometime throughout the week .

Strength is that we can collectively explore a text through productive discussions, the seminars are always an open space where everyone can contribute and learn from. Individual feedback and office hours are also very helpful in getting additional help for papers or further insight into the text.
A weakness is that the program covers too much text and we often spend too little time on the texts.

One of the strengths of the class was the passions which both professors brought to seminar. They were both extremely knowledgeable on much of the material, and their enthusiasm for sharing this knowledge with us was evident; this kind of energy is contagious. I think the biggest weakness was that co-teaching sometimes led to the two professors stepping on each other's toes. Sometimes it was evident that they had not co-ordinated the lesson plan enough beforehand, which led to some awkwardness in seminar.
The discussion format of this course was very enjoyable. It helped us better understand the texts we were reading.
small size is good

The strengths of this course were that the professors were very engaging and willing to help students understand how to better themselves. Like all DS courses, though, you're expected to write papers very well before entering the class, which can be hard.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think online seminars is a decent format. I wish it was not so early in the morning.

I feel as if the COVID adaptation of this course was great. Most of the course was seminar discussions and that was easily transferred to a zoom discussion. The lectures were recorded and uploaded (although sometimes there were times that lectures were unavailable to be watched). Overall, I feel as if this course was excellently adapted considering the circumstances.

I think the use of zoom for seminars an virtual office hours were very well managed. But there have been multiple occasions when students were confused because different professors posted the recorded lecture in different locations.
Overall i think it can be helpful if we unify the online practices like paper submission or lecture posting through canvas.
The discussion format felt as "in-person" as one could be during this time. The prerecorded lectures also helped. Overall, this course was adapted very well in gearing towards COVID-19.
seminar is good
The professors would sometimes ask other people to engage in discussions and foster participation in those that didn't speak often.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!! They are both lovely professors and DS is truly a wonderful experience.

Yes, but only if they were truly interested in the curriculum. The workload is HEAVY and there is a paper due between the three DS classes every week. The discussions are a strict discussion of ancient texts; If you find those boring, you will not like DS or DS Lit. If interested in the material, then I would definitely recommend! It's a fun course for someone who is interested in antiquity and/or someone who has no exposure to the classics.

Yes, but just like all of Directed Studies, I would warn them that they shouldn't take it unless they enjoy reading. If you're not willing to actually finish the assigned texts, the class is pointless.
Yes, I would recommend this course especially if you have an interest in the early Greek and Roman texts.
yes
I would recommend this course to a student that wishes to better their skills at interpreting literature texts and writing deep and insightful essays.
